messageBody:
On 11/30/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> But it means something completely different. This is what I get for
> trying to be clever and concise at the same time. [1]
>
> assertThat(valueOf(button).isEnabled(), eventually(eq(true)));
>
> ...only is useful in a multi-threaded situation, in which the button
> may not be enabled the first time you check, but if you wait a while,
> it should soon become enabled. The great thing is that this idea of
> repeatedly evaluating an expression, checking against a desired
> result, and then waiting before evaluating again is all encapsulated
> within the "valueOf" and "eventually" methods. Once I figured this
> out, my asynchronous UI tests actually became readable.


Oh, ok, so there is a lot more at work than assertions here, and this is a
separate (albeit very interesting) topic from literate assertions. I would
definitely hide this kind of complexity (such as invokeLater(), join(),
etc...) in utility functions.

FYI, here are a few ways you can test asynchronous code (e.g. UI or JMS)
with TestNG <http://beust.com/weblog/archives/000236.html>.

The literacy is actually secondary here, which is why I'm willing to
> live with and(greaterThan(10), lessThan(20)) when I have to [2]. The
> primary win is that the thing you're trying to assert is separated
> from the act of asserting


I'm a bit confused by this, which sounds interesting, but which I can't
connect to your following examples:

, so that you can write:
> assertThat(button, eventually(isEnabled())); // will become enabled
> or
> assertThat(button, isEnabled()); // is now enabled
> or
> assertThat(button, not(isEnabled())); // is disabled


In all these cases, it looks like both the assert and the evaluation of the
assert are executed at the same time, can you clarify? (maybe by explaining
what eventually() really does?)

--
Cédric
